links.text1: The rapid acceptance of anesthesia in 1846 aids in the secularization of pain, making way for morphine and opium use in pain treatment.
links.text2: The American Pain Society develops 'Pain as the Fifth Vital Sign' to subjectively diagnose pain patients. Studies showing inadequate pain treatment by physicians start to surface.
links.title: Pain As The Predecessor

links.text1: Due to it's higher potency allowing for smaller, less frequent doses, Heroin is created in 1898 and sold commercially by Bayer as a 'non-addictive' substitute for morphine.
links.text2: OxyContin is approved as the first formulation of oxycodone that allowed dosing every 12 hours instead of every 4 to 6 hours, marketing it as non-addictive.
links.title: 'Non-Addictive' Alternatives

links.text1: A rise in Heroin-related admissions to hospitals and concern from the American Medical Association and other officials slows the widespread prescription of Heroin.
links.text2: According to CDC data, opioid prescribing peaks in 2012 but soon starts to decline due to public concern over Oxycontin's mismarketing. Doctors become hesitant to prescribe OxyContin.
links.title: A Drop in Prescriptions

links.text1: The 1915 Harrison Act severely restricts the sale and possession of Heroin and other narcotic drugs but does little else to address the ongoing crisis. By 1924, Heroin is outlawed.
links.text2: New guidelines for treating pain outlined by the CDC have been in development for the past 2 decades. Despite these efforts, the destruction of the modern epidemic continues.
links.title: Too Little Too Late, Legislation

links.text1: The stigmatization and criminalization of those remaining struggling with an opioid use disorder makes room for the devastation caused by the nation's first epidemic to recede from memory.
links.text2: Richard Sackler, President of Purdues Pharma at the time, makes false claims that opioid abuse was no fault of the pharmaceutical industry in an infamous email to his consitiuents, weaponizing the century long stigmitization of people struggling with addiction.
links.title: Blame the Users and Introduce Stigma
